title: Mum utterly transforms her kitchen but spends just £110 doing it
text:

Mum Katy Tate had just moved into her new home, but wasn't entirely happy with the kitchen.

"The brown and blue weren't really to my taste and it was all quite dated - I just wanted to put my own stamp on it," the the 32-year-old from Durham said.

But getting a new one was more than she was prepared to spend with twin girls Mabel and Edie, two, to think about as well.

"We were quoted £4,000 for a completely new kitchen and we could've gone for it, but we chose to take our twin girls on holiday to Disney instead," marketing manager Katy explained.

"We weighed up the options and thought our money would be better spent on creating memories with our daughters, so we opted for something more temporary for the kitchen."

(Image: Katy Tate / Mercury Press & Media)

(Image: Katy Tate / Mercury Press & Media)

But after staring at the dated designs for too long, Katy took matters into her own hands, working with husband Jason to update it herself.

"Last month, I started working on the kitchen on a whim because I'd had enough of the brown cupboards," she said.

"I gave it a go despite everyone putting off doing anything to the kitchen at all because they said it would look a mess and would be hard to do."

(Image: Katy Tate / Mercury Press & Media)

Katy used paint on the cupboards, £30 vinyl designed for bathroom floors for the tiles, then finished off with wood effect sticky back plastic to update the kitchen counters.

She picked up tins of paint on sale for £12 in B&M Bargains to cover the brown wooden cabinets and cupboards in the kitchen.

Next the kitchen counters were treated with wood-effect sticky back plastic for £5 a roll.

The tile-effect was created using vinyl first meant for her bathroom floor, costing £15 a pack.

(Image: Katy Tate / Mercury Press & Media)

Next were the floors, with parquet effect 'wooden' flooring made from lino added to finish the effect.

"I'm very pleased with how it all came so cheaply and I'm surprised at the durability so far after having it up for three weeks - I couldn't envision cooking Christmas dinner in the old one!

"My husband's friend even came into our home and said 'I didn't realise you'd bought a new kitchen."
description: After being quoted £4,000 to fix up the kitchen in her new house, savvy mum Katy Tate transformed it herself for a fraction of the price, and took her twins to Disney with the money instead
